chapter.title: JAX-RS 2.1 Additions
chapter.para: JAX-RS 2.1 adds more asynchronous processing support in both the Client and the Server API. The specification adds a Reactive programming style to the Client side and Server-Sent Events (SSE) protocol support to both client and server.

sect1.title: Rective Clients API
sect1.para: The specification defines a new type of invoker named RxInvoker, and a default implementation of this type named CompletionStageRxInvoker. CompletionStageRxInvoker implements Java 8's interface CompletionStage. This interface declares a large number of methods dedicated to managing asynchronous computations.
There is also a new rx method which is used in a similar manner to async.

sect1.title: Server-Sent Events (SSE)
sect1.para: Server-sent events provides a way to establish a one-way channel from a server to a client. The connection is long running and it is re-used for multiple events sent from the server.

sect2.title: SSE Client API
sect2.para: The SSE entry point in the client API is the SseEventSource class. This object is constructed from a WebTarget. It does not duplicate any functionality in WebTarget. It only adds the necessary logic for SSE.
Clients request an SSE connection by using the special media type text/event-stream in the Accept header.

sect2.title: SSE Server API
sect2.para: The SSE server API is used to accept connections and send events to one or more clients. A resource method that injects an SseEventSink and produces the media type text/event-stream is an SSE resource method.

sect2.title: Broadcasting
sect2.para: SSE provides a way to broadcast events to multiple clients simultaneously. Multiple SseEventSinkâ€™s can be registered on a single SseBroadcaster object.

sect1.title: Java API for JSON Binding
sect1.para: RESTEasy supports both JSON-B and JSON-P. In accordance with the specification, entity providers for JSON-B take precedence over those for JSON-P for all types except JsonValue and its sub-types.
